zone.line: ¶Lo here folowethe the deuyse of a desguysinge to fore the grete
estates of this land than beinge at london made by lidgate
daun Iohnn the munke of bury / of dame fortune dame prudence
dame rightwysnesseThis underline is bracketed on the right. and dame ffortitudoBracketed on the right. behold it for it is
morall plesaunt and notabell / loThe attributed title in the DIMEV entry for this manuscript witness has "to," but the glyph is clearly "lo." first cometh in dame fortuneBracketed on the right.
LooThe space between "l" and "oo" makes it clear that "l" is intended as a guide letter here. here this lady that ye may see
lady of mutabilyte
whych that called is fortune
for selde in one she dothe continewe
ffor as she hathe a doubell face
right so euery oure and space
she chaungeth hur condysyones
ay full of transmutacyons
lyche as the romaynes of the rose
descryveth hur / with outen glose
and telleth pleynly / how that she
hath hur dwellynge in the see
IoyningeWhile elsewhere in the manuscript there is a differentiation between the "I" and "J" glyphs it is inconsistent and nonexistent in this particular item. to a baryn roche
and on that on syde doth approche
alytell mountayn lyke an yle

vponn whyche land somme ylemewhyleIt looks like the scribe originally wrote "somme yle" here, but realized they had copied the final word of the previous line and corrected themselves by overwriting the fourth glyph to the third glyph from the end with "why." A suspension mark is then placed over the "w."
ther growen freshe floures nowe
wonder lusty of ther hue
dyuers tres with frute elade
and byrdes with ther notes glade
than singen / and maken melodye
In ther heuynly hermonyeIt appears that the scribe originally wrote "hermone" here, then overwrote the "n" with a "y" glyph.
some singe on hye and som lowe
and zepherusBracketed on both sides. ther doth eke blow
with his smoothe / attempre ayre
he makethe the weder / cler and fayr
And the sesoun full of grace
¶but sodenly in lytell space
vpon this place most royall
ther cometh awawe and for dereth all
ffirst the freshe floures glad
on ther stalkes / he dothe fade
to ther bewty / he doth wronge
¶and than farewell the byrdes songe
braunch and bougħe of euery tre
she robbethe them of ther beutye
leffe and blosomes doune they fall
¶and in that place / she hath an hall
departed / and wonder disgysee
ffrom that on syde / ye maye see
curyouslyTrinity R.3.20 has "Ceryously" here. wrough for the nones
of gold and sylluer and of stones
whos richesse / may not be tould
¶but that other syde / of that hold
Is obylte in ugly wyse
and ruynous / for to deuyse
daubed of claynesTrinity R.3.20 has "clay is" here. that doungeoun
ay in poynt to fall adoun
that on fayre / by apparence
and that other in existence
shaken with wyndes rayne and hayle
and sodenly ther doth assayle
a rage flud / that mancyon
and ouer floweth it vp and doune
her is no rescnes / ner obstacle
of this ladyes habytacle
¶and as hur hous is aye vnstabell
ryght so hir sellfe is deseuabellTrinity R.3.20 has deceyuable
In no poynte she is neuer alytche
this daye she maketh aman all rytche
and thorough hisrThe scribe originally had "his" here, but realized their mistake and replaced it with "hir." mutabylite
casteth hym to morowe / in pouerte
the proudest / she can gyue afalle
she made alexaunder wynnen all
that no man him with stand dare
and caste him doun / or he was ware
So did she sesar IuliusBracketed on both sides.
she made him first victorius
thoughe to doo well she be full lothe
of a bakers sone in sothe
she made him amighty emperour
and hool of rome was gouernoure
maugrey the senat / and all ther myghte
But whan the sonne / shone most bright
of his tryumphe / fer and nere
and he was corouned / with laurnier
vnworthy thorough / his mortalle lawe
with bodkyns / he was eslawe
at the capitaylle / in Consistorye
loo / affter all his gret victory
sesar a bakers sone
¶see how this lady can appalle
the noblesse of thos prynces all
she hath two tunys in her seller
that on is full / of pyment cler
confectTrinity R.3.20 has "confeit." with suger and spyces swete
and mannys delectabell roote
but this is yet the worste of all
that other time is full of gall
who tasteth one / ther is non other
he moste taste eke of that other
¶whos sodeyne chaynges ben not soffte
ffor now she can raysse one alofte
ffrom lowgħe estate / till hye degre
In ould storyes / ye may see
estates chaunge / who taketh kepe
¶ffor on gygesBracketed on each side. that kept shepe
she mad by vertue of a rynge
ffor to be made / a worthy kynge
and by fals mourdre / I dare expresse
he cameThe scribe has overwritten the final minim of "m" here with an "e" to all his worthynesse
moste odyous / of all thynges
and cresisBracketed on both sides richest of all kynges
was so surgedus / in his pryde
that he went vppon no syde
non erthly thinge might hym perturbe
nor hys ryall estate disturbe
¶till on a night adreme he mette
how IuboTrinity R.3.20 has "Iuvo." in the ayre hym sette
and Iubiter / he vnderstondes
¶ecclesiasticus
xxxi cap

gaue himThis could be "hys," but comparison with "his" beginning the fourth line on this page suggests that it's meant as "him," especially when the latter is compared with "hys" on this line. water vnto hys handes
and phebusBracketed on both sides. held him the towayle
but of this dreme the devynaile
his daughter gaue to specyfye
and for to forne to prophesye
whych called leryopeeBracketed on both sides.
she sayde he shuld an hanged be

this was hir exposicyounyAs with other items in this witness a "y" or "h" appears as the final glyph of words with the "oun" ending. However, unlike with other examples the "y" appears to have been struck out here.
loo how hir pryde was brought adoun
¶and all thos chaunges / yf they be sought
this falls lady hath them wrought
aualed with ther sodayne shures
the worthynesseThe scribe forgot the "n", and has included it above the space between "y" and "e" in this word. of conqueroures
rede of poetes the comedyes
and in dyuers tragedyes
ye shall by lamentacyons
ffynden ther distruccyons
athousande mo / than I can tell
Inn to myscheffe how they fell
doune from hir wheell / on see and lande
¶yet for hir malys / to withstandTrinity R.3.20 has "Þer-fore" rather than "yet" here.
hir pompe hir surquydye / hir pryd
yf she woll / a whyle abyd
foure ladyes shall come here anon
whicħ shall hir power / ouergone
and the malyce / eke oppresse
of this blynd falls goddesse
yff she be hardy in this place
onys for to show hir double face
¶Now kometh here the first lady of the foure dame prudenceBracketed on both sides.
Loo here this lady in your presence
of poetes called is dame prudenceBracketed on the left.
the whych / with hir merour bright
and hyr myrrour called prouydenceBracketed on both sides.
Is stronge to make resistence
In hur foresight as it is right
agayngst fortune / and all hur myght
ffor senecBracketed on the left. sayth who that can se
that prudenceBracketed on both sides. hath eyegħon thre
speciallye in hur lokynges
To consider thre maner thynges
allwyes by good auysement
thinges passed and eke presente
and thinges aft that shall fall
and she not looke / first of all
and done hir Inward besy peyne
thinges presente for to ordeyne
auysely on euery side
and future thinges for to provyde
the thinges passed in substaunce
ffor to haue in remembraunce
and who thus dothe I saye that he
verrayly hath eygħen thre
comitted vnto his deffence
the truue myrrour of prouydenceBracketed on the left side.
¶than this lady is hys gyde
hym to defend / on euery syde
agayne fortune goode and peruerse
and all hir power for to reuerse
ffor fraunchysed and lybertieThe EETS edition adds "[at]" prior to "liberte," which is missing here.
from hys power to goo free
stond alle folkes in sentence
which byn gouerned by prudenceBracketed on both sides.
.i. providencia
¶Now sheweth hyr here the second lady dame ryghtwysnesseBracketed on both sides.
¶Soth here this lady rightwyssnes
of all vertues she is prycesse
for by the scales of hur ballaunce
she sett them all in gouernaunce
she putteth asyde it is no drede
frenshipe fauour / and all hinesTrinity R.3.20 has "kyns" here. It seems likely that the scribe misinterpreted the initial letter of the exemplar. nedeTrinity R.3.20 has "meede"
loue and dredeBracketed on both sides. She setteth at noughte
ffor rightfull dome may not be boughte
and ryghtwysnesBracketed on the right. who can esspye
hath neyther hand nor eygheThe second glyph appears to have been written over with an "y" but it is unclear what the scribe originally wrote here.
she loste hur hand full ther agone
ffor she reseyueth gyftes none
nother of frend nother of foo
and she hath lost hur syght allso
for of ryghte she dothe provyde
nought for to loke on neyther syde
to hyghe estate no lowe degre
but doth to bodenTrinity R.3.20 has "boþen" here. all equyte
and maketh non excepcion
to nayther part but of rayson
And for the purpos of this matter
of a Iuge ye shall here
which neuer his lyffe of entent
ther passed no Iudgemente
by his lippes of falsenesse
of whome the story doth expresse
after his dethe / by accountes cler
more than thre hundred yeare

his body as is made mencyousyAs is seen elsewhere in the manuscript a word we might expect to terminate in an "n" instead terminates in either a "y" or "h." Here, however, it looks like the scribe first wrote an "s" and then corrected it to "y."
was tourned vnto corrupcyouyAs mentioend in the previous note, the final word of this line terminates with "y."
the story telleth it is no dred
but lyche aroos / swet and red
mouth and lippes were yfounde
nougħte corrupte / but hole and sounde
ffor truth that he did expresse
in all his domes of ryghtwyssenes
¶ffor this lady / with that balaunce
was with hym of acquayntaunce
which him made in his ententes
to gyue also ryghtwyse Iugemente
wherfore this lady which ye here see
with hur balaunce of equyteThe scribe forgot the "u" after the "q" glyph here, and has added it between "q" and "u"
hath the scales hanged soo
that she hath nothynge to doo
neuer with fortunesBracketed on both sides. doubellnesse
for euer in on state ryghtwysenesseBracketed on both sides.
no wher mouinge to ne fro
in no thynge that she hath to do
¶Lo here kometh in now the third lady called fortitudoBracketed on both sides.
¶Taketh hede this fayre lady loo /
I called is fortitudoBracketed on the right.
whan philosophers by ther sentence
ar wante to clepe magnyfycenceBracketed on the left.
and fortitudoBracketed on both sides. sothly she hyghte
ageyne all vyces for to fyghte
agaynste ałł aduersyte
in signe wher of she bereth aswerdeThe scribe originally had written a different word here but corrected themselves by writing over the section after "as" with "werde."
That she of nothinge is a ferde
ffor common profit also she
off verry magnanymyte
thinges gret doth vnderfonge
takinge in prysesTrinity R.3.20 has "enpryses" here, which provides a different reading. / which ben stronge
and moste she doth hir pouer preue
a communalteThere is an otiose tittle over what should be the final glyph before the "a" in this word. for to releve
namely vpon a grounde of truth
than in hir ther is no slouthe
ffor to mayntayn the good comune
and also the assaultes of fortune
of verrey stedfastnesse of thoughte
all hir chaunges / she sette at noughte
ffor this uertu magnyfycence
thorough hir mighty excellence

she armed thos philosophers couldeTrinity R.3.20 has "oolde" here, which might fit better, but the structure of words like "comune" in line nineteen of this section and "cometh" in the incipt, when compared with "smoothe" in the third line of f.140r and "doo" in the third line from the top of f.141 indicate that this is meant to be a "co" construction.
off wordly thinge / that they nought tould
recorde vpon dyogenesBracketed on both sides
on platoBracketed on both sides. and on socratesBracketed on both sides
she made cypionnBracketed on the left. of cartage
to vnderfonge in hys age
ffor comune preufyte thinges grete
and for no dred list not lett
agaynst rome that mighty toune
for to defende his g regyon
she made hectorBracketed on the left for hys cite
to spare for non adversyte
but as amyghty champyon
in the defence of troyes toun
to dye with outen fere or dred
and thus this lady who taketh hed
makith hur champyons stronge
parralus thinges to vunderfonge
till that they ther purpose fyne
record of the worthes nyne
off / other eke that were but late
InThe EETS edition corrects this to "I," in one of the few instances of correction that MacCraken noted. meane prynces / of latter date
henry the fyfte / I dare seye soo
he myght be tould for on of the
empryses that were begonne
he left not til they wer wonne
and I supposse / and yow list see
that thos ladyes all thre
were of his counsayle doutles
.i. republica
fforce prudenceBracketed on the right and rightwysnesseBracketed on the right.
off thos thre / he toke his roote
to putt fortune vnder fott
and sith this ladye / in vertu stronge
soustayneth trouth and doth it wronge
late hur now to more and lasse
be welcome to yow this cristmasse
¶And this edone cometh in the forthe lady cleped
dame feyre and wyse attempraunce
¶This fayre lady that ye sene here
humble debonare / and sadd of chere
I called is attemperaunce
to sett all thinge in gouernaunce
and for hir susters to provyd
vyces all shall circumsyde
and setten them in stabulnesse
with hir cousin soburnesseBracketed on the right.
she shall from vyces them restreyne
and in vertue hold hur reyne
and ther in gyue them liberte
eschuynge all dishoneste
and them in furmen by prudence
ffor to haue pacyence
lownesse and humylite
and pryd specially to flee
contynence from glotenye
eschue dishonest companye
fflen the dyte and the tauerne
and in soburnesse them gouerne

with hart allIt appears that the final glyph has been stuck out, but this may simply be a smudge. Both "al" and "all" appear in this work, and so I've decided to err on the side of assuming it is a mistake. euer they can
In vertu louen euery man
sey the best ay of entent
who that seyth well doth not repente
¶detraction and gloteny
voyde them from thy company
and all rancoure sett asyde
be not to hasty / but euer abyde
specially to done vengaunce
¶in abode it no repentaunce
and in vertu / who is thus sett
than be thos susters well Imett
and sothly yf it be discerned
who by thos foure / is thus gouerned
¶thus I meane that by prudence
he haue the myrrour of prouydence
ffor to consider thinges all
namely parylles / or they fall
¶and who that haue by gouernaunce
of ryghtwysnes the ballaunce
and strongly hold in his deffence
the swerd of hir magnyfycence
ye bene assured / from all myschaunce
¶namely whan that attemperaunce

hirIt is possible that this is "y" with a tittle, but as y appears elsewhere in the manuscript without any sort of indication I believe it's more likely that this is intended as "i." suster gouerneth all thre
ffrom fortuneBracketed on the right. ye may than go fre
both allwye / in hert and thought

whyle ye be so / no dred hurThis, when compared with "hir" at lines two and six of this section, provides a particularly good example of how the two forms of the word throughout are "hir" and "hur," respectively. nought
but avoydeth / hir acqueyntaunce
ffor hir double varyaunce
and fleeth oute of hir company
and all that ben of hur allye
and ye foure susters glad of chere
shuld abyde here all this yeare
IinnThe scribe wrote the initial "I" here, then immediately followed it with "in." Realizing the error it appears they completed the "n," but the tittle for "i" was left. this housould at liberte
and Ioye and all prosparyte
with you to housold ye shuld bring
and ye all foure shall now syng
with all your hole herte entier
some new songe aboute the fyre
suche on as you lyketh best
lat ffortune go playe hir wher hir liste / explicit
